High school students in Ms. Grunstein's class have been learning about the Dada Art movement and how "Ready Mades" led to found object and assemblage art. The design challenge for this project was to produce sculptures that depict the negative effects that the modern materials economy can have on either humans, wildlife or the environment as a whole. To better understand these "hidden costs," students viewed The Story of Stuff. For artistic inspiration, the group examined how early as well as current found object artists used materials to communicate social and environmental issues with special focus on artist Betye Saar and artist/community organizer Angela Haseltine Pozzi of the Washed Ashore initiative.

Five high school students will be featured this week. Today’s work is by ninth-grader Tatiana.

The Center for Holocaust, Human Rights and Genocide Education (Chhange) launched its work with our middle school this past week. The first visit had a team of writers and genocide educators work with all of English teacher Michelle Paxton’s classes. The program is titled "Building Bridges.” This first round of work had kids creating “Found Poems.”

Chhange Educator Susan Stein engaged the students in close reading and analysis of diary excerpts written by three adolescents during their Holocaust Experience: Anonymous Girl (Łódź Ghetto), David Sierakowiak (Łódź Ghetto) and Anne Frank (hiding in Amsterdam). Susan also included a letter written by Etty Hillesum (young woman in Westerbork Transit Camp, the Netherlands). Each poem attached came out of collaborative work within each the classes. Each phrase in the poems is constructed by an individual student (using only Etty’s words from the letter). The students then combined their phrases into the “Class Found Poem.”

Skyping With Author Kevin Kurtz!

Students in Ms. Leaper and Ms. Stodolksi's third grade classes study nonfiction books and eventually craft their own expository texts. To help bring this learning to life, the two teachers reached out to a nonfiction author, Kevin Kurtz, via Skype for an interview. The students prepared by studying nonfiction texts, generating relevant and appropriate questions, and practicing their own interviews before hosting him virtually in our classroom. During the interview, he gave a brief overview of himself, shared how and why he became a writer, and discussed his own writing process. The students were able to ask questions and record notes during the interview!
